title: Creating an Inequality
text: First, we must transfer the word problem into an inequality that represents the total earning Joni makes.
speech: First, we must transfer the word problem into an inequality that represents the total earning Joni makes.
pacedSpeech: First, we must transfer the word problem into an inequality that represents the total earning Joni makes.

title: Creating an Inequality
text: We know that Joni wants her earning to be at least $1000, and each kitchen apron can be sold for $$\$32.50$$. If we let $$x$$ represent the number of kitchen aprons Joni sells, then her total earning would be $$32.5x$$. Therefore, we have the inequality $$32.5x \geq 1000$$.
speech: We know that Joni wants her earning to be at least $1000, and each kitchen apron can be sold for  dollars 32.50, . If we let  x  represent the number of kitchen aprons Joni sells, then her total earning would be  32.5 x . Therefore, we have the inequality  32.5 x is greater than or equal to, 1000 .

title: Solving the Inequality
text: Now, we must solve the inequality for $$x$$ by algebrically manipulating it.
speech: Now, we must solve the inequality for  x  by algebrically manipulating it.

title: Solving the Inequality
text: To do this, we can divide both sides by $$32.5$$ to isolate $$x$$. We now have $$x \geq 30.77$$ as our inequality.
speech: To do this, we can divide both sides by  32.5  to isolate  x . We now have  x is greater than or equal to, 30.77  as our inequality.

title: Creating a Sentence-Answer
text: Since $$x$$ must be greater than or equal to $$30.77$$ and $$x$$ has to be a whole number, what is the minimum number of kitchen aprons Joni has to sell?
